[b] > Be me, just a casual gamer looking for some fun  
> Hear about this game called "World of Goo," intrigued  
> Download.exe  
> Expecting some casual gooey fun, not disappointed  
> Boot up the game, greeted by cute goo blobs with big eyes  
> Feelsgoodman.jpeg  
> Tutorial: Drag goo, build structures, reach the pipe  
> Easy peasy, right? Nah, things get gooey  
> "The Goo Balls are alive... and curious," it says  
> Wait, what? These blobs have personalities?  
> Spend 10 minutes naming my favorite goo ball - call him "Goober"  
> Goober becomes my goo spirit animal  
> Start building structures, feel like an architect for goo civilizations  
> The physics, tho - like real-life Jenga but with goo  
> Spend more time giggling at my goo towers falling than succeeding  
> The music, a goo-tastic symphony of triumph and gooey defeat  
> Goo-filled landscapes, from the Goo Balls' perspective  
> These gooey challenges are oddly addictive  
> Reach the "Beauty and the Electric Tentacle" level  
> Electric Tentacle is basically the ex who shocks you but you keep going back  
> Goober sacrifices himself for the greater goo  
> RIP Goober, you magnificent goo ball  
> "The Goo Balls believe you are the Sign Painter."  
> The Sign Painter, the unsung hero of goo storytelling  
> Falls in love with the Sign Painter's goo puns  
> "You're ahead of the curve, Early Worm gets the Goos!"  
> MFW I realize I've fallen for a game about goo  
> Finish the game, feeling accomplished and gooey inside  
> 10/10 would let the goo consume my life again  
> Goober, my gooey hero, forever in my gooey heart  
> World of Goo, where goo is life, and life is gooey. 🌍💖🔧 [/b]

King Harkinian is lounging on his royal throne, surrounded by Zelda, Link, Morshu, Ganon, and Gwonam. A massive screen flickers to life, revealing King Harkinian with a game controller in hand.

HARKINIAN: (with a grand gesture) Gather around, my esteemed Hyrule subjects! Today, we embark on an epic quest in the World of Goo! 🌍🏰

The group exchanges confused glances, but Harkinian presses play.

ZELDA: (raising an eyebrow) Father, are you sure this is a wise use of our time?

HARKINIAN: Wise, my dear Zelda? Nay! But it is a gooey adventure that shall entertain us!

The World of Goo title screen appears, gooey blobs dancing.

LINK: (pointing at the screen) Hyah! What's that, Princess? Strange creatures!

HARKINIAN: (grinning) These are Goo Balls, my loyal subjects! We shall guide them to victory!

Harkinian starts building goo structures in the first level.

MORSHU: (rubbing his hands together) Ah, yes! Building towers of goo! Perhaps there's a way to sell Goo Balls in my shop...

GANON: (sarcastically) A truly nefarious plan, Morshu.

MORSHU: (with a sly grin) Come back when you're a little... gooier! 💣👛

Harkinian struggles with a goo tower, causing laughter among the group.

GWONAM: (stroking his beard) The Prince of All Cosmos would be proud of this goo-rrific creation!

HARKINIAN: (narrating) Fear not, my loyal subjects, for I am the master of goo engineering! 🏗️

The Goo Balls react with joy as the tower reaches the pipe.

ZELDA: (surprised) Father, you did it!

HARKINIAN: (basking in glory) Indeed! Now, witness my gooey prowess!

Harkinian continues to navigate through challenging gooey puzzles.

LINK: (enthusiastically) Hyah! These Goo Balls are more daring than a Dodongo in a dark cave!

GANON: (muttering) I could conquer kingdoms more efficiently than this gooey nonsense.

GANON: (evil chuckle) Enough of this gooey nonsense! I'll create a goo army and rule Hyrule with a sticky fist! 🌍🏰

As Harkinian reaches a challenging level, Morshu leans in.

MORSHU: (whispering) Need any bombs to clear the goo, my friend?

HARKINIAN: (ignoring Morshu) The Sign Painter speaks the truth! Embrace the goo, and the goo will embrace you! 🖌️

Ganon smirks as the group gets more engrossed in the gooey adventure.

GANON: (slyly) Perhaps this gooey world could use a touch of darkness. Goo-na rule it all! 😈🖤

Harkinian completes the last level, and the room erupts in applause.

HARKINIAN: (triumphant) We have triumphed in the World of Goo! Now, let us feast in celebration! 🍖🎉

The group exits the room, leaving the screen glowing with victorious gooiness.

FADE OUT. 🌈✨

145356392.review:
Por el año 2008 llegaba a Steam la moda indie (y muchos bundles realmente baratos) donde gran cantidad de producciones de bajo presupuesto trataban de hacerse hueco entre títulos notables vendiéndonos el concepto de que traían consigo nuevas ideas y mecánicas novedosas.

Este juego de puzzles pertenece a esa época dorada y efectivamente tiene mecánicas muy originales, controlando a unos personajes gregarios con forma (normalmente) de bola que pueden agruparse formando estructuras por las que moverse, con el objetivo final de huir de cada escenario a través de una tubería que les succiona cuando están a la distancia adecuada, así que básicamente el objetivo del juego es acercarles hasta ella. Su curva de dificultad es asequible y tenemos cierto margen no siendo necesaria la perfección salvándoles siempre a todos, y sus melodías le dan dinamismo.

El único punto negativo (aparte de su estética, que va por gustos) es que tiene problemas notables de rendimiento probablemente debidos a sus gráficos tipo flash y además carecer completamente de ajustes gráficos, en un PC moderno he llegado a verlo por debajo de 30fps, aunque se podría forzar el modo ventana no es tan importante como puede parecer al ocurrir en momentos puntuales como desplazarnos deprisa por el escenario cuando hay muchos personajes en pantalla. De todas formas tiene demo en Steam así que es muy fácil comprobar como nos rendirá. Por lo demás bastante recomendable.

It surprises to see this game is from so long ago because the themes it presents feel very relevant as of recent, this game undoubtly holds up today and is must play for anyone, including those who don't like video games, thats how important World of Goo is.

143138834.review:
It's a remarkable puzzle game that uses physics to create interesting levels. You use «Goo balls» to build various structures, with the goal of overcoming obstacles and reaching the end of the level.

Physics:
The use of physics in «World of Goo» is interesting. The construction of complex structures requires an understanding and application of basic principles of physics, which makes each level unforgettable and engaging.

Online:
At the end of the game, a new mode opens where players can compete by building their own towers from the remaining «Goo balls». This mode is a wonderful addition to the main game and gives players the opportunity to use their skills in a new context.

143002574.review: Seeing a promotional video for this game on the Nintendo Channel, a Wii channel for watching game trailers, original shows, and downloading demos for DS games, as a young kid. For this World of Goo will always have a special place in my heart.  The physics puzzles are intuitive and satisfying and the style is delightful. I cant recommend it enough.

141116194.review:
I was expecting World of Goo to be the type of game you try for 5 minutes then drop out of boredom. To my surprise it hooked me instantly thanks to how well its paced and how almost every new level introduces a new mechanic.
At its core, it is a physics based puzzle game and although it might look like those regular bridge building games at first, World of Goo has so much going on under its hood that it would be an insult to categorize it like that. 
Charming visuals sounds and music, engaging gameplay and a mysterious story make World of Goo a treat to play.
I recommend everyone to try it.

129788420.review:
[h1]What Amazing Indie games used to be[/h1]
[hr][/hr][i]Dangerously cute. Story with a twist. Novel, simple, but addicting gameplay. World of Goo symbolises the best qualities of original indie games. It is a really good game and one of the classics.[/i][hr][/hr]
[h1]The Three Pillars[/h1]
It is difficult to review such games, because they are small, focused and polished. You either like what this game is trying to do or this game isn't for you. There are no complex systems which would not function as advertised. There are no over-ambitious marketing. There is no confusion in a game genre and on what aspects game should focus and to what game's sub-audience it should appeal. You either like what you see from trailer or you do not as you had seen the whole game at that point.
[list]
[b][i]Gameplay[/i][/b]
[*]Gameplay had charmed me back in a day. It was simple, addictive and surprisingly deep. You can use various building blocks to attach them to each other. As your structure grows, you have to balance its weight not to tip over your structure. Likewise, your GooBalls are alive. They constantly move around the structure and in their excitement they can tip your beautiful tower down. Game also tests your knowledge fully in free build mode where you collect gooballs from all the levels and build them into a massive tower or in epilogue with last three hardest levels of a game.

[b][i]Aesthetics[/i][/b] 
[*]To me this game is beautiful. I love such simple, cute looking games. Nothing what isn't supposed to be here is here. Your building blocks are personified and part of living world. Levels represent part of a greater world. Something as mundane as a gap to sewer system is a level in this game. It is not stated as obviously, but a lot of levels do take mundane things and make them into oversized obstacles. This gives game a strong narrative feel. You are not simply doing random things. You are part of a living world. World which is tied to the story. To motivation of your GooBalls. This simplicity of design and adorable artwork is something which I really love seeing in games.

[b][i]Story[/i][/b]
[*]Story is minimal, clever and with a twist. I do love how it manages to be a meta commentary without feeling forced. I love humour in it. I love how this twist is always hinted through environment, but it is never told you directly. Game does not try to force itself upon you. This is why I had enjoyed this game for what it was.

There is also a sign. It is a small background element which gives usually a short message. It sits in a background and if you want to press it, you can. As level progresses, you might eventually see more of them scattered across the level. It is a clever way to add developer commentary. I liked humour in it. I liked how story was portrayed through them. I liked consciousness which post sign had ironically tried to portray.
[/list]

[h1]One of the Classics[/h1]
To me this game represents what a lot of games should be. They should try to accomplish one simple thing. They should not be overloaded with unnecessary mechanics. This game is simple. It is as long as it has to be. It does not overstay its welcome. Each design element which is in this game is part of core gameplay. Everything is polished to the mirror finish. It is a game which I'm glad that I came back to play again. I started from start and finished it. It was fun little game to play in short bursts. I'm glad that I came back to play this game.

A classic construction game that, while it isn't very complex or challenging, stands out due to its art style, tone, and atmosphere.

The atmosphere in this game is great; the bright colors paired with overly industrial grays lead to this cheerful-yet-dreary feeling that's almost unique to World of Goo and other Tomorrow Company games.

Doesn't last too long (5-6 hours), but is a nice nostalgia trip.

110702279.review:
★☆☆☆☆ Terrible

[h1]Puzzle[/h1]

The concept behind this game is great. It's a physics puzzler where you build goo based structures in order to save a collection of goo balls.

The problem lies in the concept's execution. The OCD challenges are what give replay value to the game but are frustrating to an incredible degree. Some of the challenges require you to finish the level within a certain amount of time, but don't offer you a timer during the game. You have to wait until you finish the level to see your completion time. This means that you have to go back to the world map and then reselect the level again in order to retry. A similar frustration is that you can't retry the level after the base number of goo balls have been collected. Some of the OCD challenges require you to collect and absurd amount of goo balls compared to the amount required to complete the level on its own.

World of Goo also has a gameplay mode that lets you build an infinitely tall tower of goo. This would be cool if you got anything for building a taller and taller structure but all it seems to do is allow you to compete with other people. The goo you collect from the "story" part of the game gets sent to the Corporation of Goo where you build the infinite tower. It would be nice if building a taller and taller tower unlocked something or other because otherwise there's no motivation to even use this part of the game. The music is good as well, but there's no option to turn it off.

All in all, this game frustrated the hell out of me. Not because the concept was frustrating or even the gameplay, the UI and overall system built around the gameplay is what turned me off. There are features missing that are expected in modern puzzle games and features missing that are expected in modern games in general. The fact that this is an indie title is no excuse for a lack of a sound/volume menu, or the lack of a timer when challenges require you to finish a level within a time limit.

105441701.review:
World of Goo is a puzzle-plattformer / bridge builder which lets you build structures out of living goo-balls. Since they are alive and constantly moving your structures will wobble constantly, making it more difficult to stabilize the whole thing. Keeping your structure from falling apart, slowly buidling monsters which hold together by sheer willpower, is great fun and a wonderfully integrated mechanic.

Another highlight of the game are the levels, since each and every one of them comes with a unique topic and theme. It never gets boring, since there are always new challenges, ideas, colour palettes, assets, and mechanics to discover and to observe. Many of the levels are downright memorable with their settings - also something quite rare in this genre.

The difficulty is low-medium, apart from a few levels and comes mostly from the unstable character of your building material than from the puzzles themselves. If things start to fall apart you can click on "time bugs" to go back to a previous step. It can happen that you run out of those bugs, but most of the levels are short enough so that a restart does not feel like a total grind. If it is too easy for you, you can try to get the OCD achivements for each level which are more difficult, but also add to the replayability-factor of course.

The whole story takes place on a planet which was taken over by a giant cooperation. There is not much more to it, since this is just a general frame for the game. The soundtrack and the art-style is quirky and fun, just what you would expect from a whole circus of Goo-balls going nuts together.

My only real gripe is the lack of an options menu. Resolution or graphics cannot be changed, sound cannot be adjusted etc.. It worked fine for me, still it would have been a nice to have.

Overall, if you have even the slightest interest in the genre, this is an absolute no brainer, and despite its age it will be a great addition to your collection!

World of Goo is a physics puzzle game based around connecting bridges of little goo balls to reach a pipe at the end. Simple, right? Well, so it seems, at the very least. With a booming orchestral score, somber yet eye-catching visuals, and odd-ball writing left behind by the mysterious and possibly mad Sign Painter, World of Goo is certainly a game not to be looked past simply on the pretense of being "just another puzzle game". My dad bought this game on the Wii, and didn't care for it. However, I loved it and played it for hours. Keep in mind I was not good at the game whatsoever, but it's unique art style, gameplay, and charm kept me going. It took me 2 months to finish all the levels (Keep in note this was with a 12 inch TV and a buggy Wii remote!), and I eventually 100%ed the game with all the OCD flags the next year. After I did that I played it on and off, until our Wii kicked the bucket about 10 years ago. I soon forgot about the game. However, just yesterday, someone mentioned the game in a Discord server of mine, and It all came rushing back to me. I bought the game here on Steam not even 5 minutes later. I've just beaten it (Much faster, thankfully.) and am now planning to 100% it once again. My story aside, this is one of the most engaging and creative puzzle games out there, on the same level as the Portal games even, both in terms of Looks, Gameplay, and Story. Yes, this game has a story, and a surprisingly deep and meaningful one too. It can be difficult at times, but it's not frustrating because you feel like you caused whatever made you fail. I might sound like a broken record but this game is just so damn creative and fun! There's not much more I want to say, just play it already!

(P.S. Our Wii has since been repaired and is now doing fine.)

93506159.review:
[h1]Goo Gone Wrong[/h1]
[b]Summary:[/b]
A construction puzzle game meant for another platform.

[b]Review:[/b]
I'm old enough to remember the hype surrounding World of Goo when it was making its debut back when it was Tower of Goo, and marveling at both its slick presentation and broad possibilities. Slick and inventive, I saw a lot of promise in a tight package.

Instead what we see here is a port that didn't get the PC release it deserved.

[i]“But wait a second, OctoberFarts, you actual neckbear. Wasn't this on PC first?”[/i]

Yes, yes it was. Which is why I'm so confused about why it was ported so badly from mobile to PC.

[i]“That doesn't even make any sense!”[/i]

What does in this crazy [CURRENT YEAR] world of ours?

[i]“Fair enough. Go on.”[/i]

So World of Goo is a game that plays like it belongs on a phone or tablet but was actually made on PC then ported to mobile which plays better than it did on the PC platform that it was originally built on.

I love the game as a concept. Wandering balls of goo need to get from point A to point B, a bit like another classic, Lemmings. Instead of builders, diggers, blockers and such, you build with the goo itself, different colors having different abilities. They snap satisfyingly together to create towers, bridges, nets, barriers, etc, just to get what unused goo is left to the finish line, or in this case a vacuum of some sort.

You move goo balls by clicking them and dragging them together to build, often as fast or efficiently as you can, because goo is limited, and you need to help as many as you can escape the stage. Some you fling, some are balloons, and some are hard to explain.

Strategies continue evolving throughout, and I found myself really stumped in some areas, and really impressed with others. Chapter 4 was probably one of the most satisfying for me, but a great example of these puzzles done right is in the first Epilogue stage, which relies on speed, physics, timing, and creativity to overcome.

This is also where the game's greatest failings shine through.

One of the game's largest problems stems from unresponsiveness. Some of the already very challenging levels become all the more difficult when the screen won't pan fast enough, or balls would not accept being clicked or put in place quite as intended or as quickly as needed.

This makes things even harder for meeting any stage's OCD requirements (best or fastest possible solution) throughout the game. Further exacerbating this can be the way the camera doesn't pan far enough to see dangers ahead, resulting in balls lost or misplaced.

It is a frustrating design decision that could be easily accommodated if the game supported full screen modes for modern machines, or worked around this dynamic rather than crippling the player's ability to view the screen or move balls accordingly.

World of Goo makes most sense as a touch interface mobile game to which it was ported after being released on PC. It makes sense when you touch a screen to move a ball with your finger instead of clicking on it. It makes sense to swipe fingers around on the screen to see where you are going or what dangers await ahead. I even tried using my Wacom Tablet and it was still very frustrating. Though I could select balls more easily things still felt loose and unresponsive.

The music was often annoying and repetitive, and there were evidently no options included, not for volume, or even to turn it on or off.

This game was played with all settings maxed out using an Intel i7-8700k, 32gb DRAM, Samsung Evo SSD, 1080ti, running in windowed mode on a 3440x1440 monitor. Clicking outside of the window (and thus the game) happened often and easily, and considering the frantic pace this game can play at times, very inconveniently. Holding Alt-Enter will switch to full screen, but on my monitor that meant almost 50% of my view were black pillars on either side.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Novel concept
    [*]Very challenging
    [*]Clever puzzles
    [*]Creative level design holds up
    [*]Humor?
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Humor...
    [*]Some challenges unnecessarily unfair
    [*]Sloppy camera and controls
    [*]No volume or music options
    [*]Little in the way of settings
    [*]Probably a lot better on mobile devices
[/list]

[b]Verdict: 5/10[/b]

It pains me to give this one a less than glowing review because as stated, I love this game as a concept, and I respect the devs. Soft recommended, however, playing this game on PC with a mouse reminds me of trying to draw in MS Paint with a mouse; [b]DON'T.[/b]

92345338.review:
World of Goo is a game that has followed me through my entire life. I first played it on Wiiware and fell in love with it immediately. This is the debut game from publisher 2D Boy, (now known as the Tomorrow Corporation) and despite it's rough edges is a wonderful example of the creativity of the puzzle game genre. In this game, you are tasked with navigating a group of goo balls to a pipe, usually on the other side of the level. You can tether the goo balls to each other to create a tower to the pipe which allows the stray goo to exit. As the game goes on you'll meet new varieties of goo that create new and interesting puzzles. The game is a perfect length, at four chapters and an epilogue. It's story is short and straight to the point. I look back fondly on key parts of the story, especially chapter four. It goes in a direction visually and in it's puzzles that is wildly unique and unexpected. All throughout the game Kyle Gabler's compositions complement the interesting world and storytelling, though I wish there were a few more tracks. The OST is a good length, at 27 pieces, but several levels reuse the same tracks and it'd be fun if this didn't have to be the case. On top of this some of the tracks feel a little unpolished, but this can be overlooked considering the conditions the game was developed under. 2D Boy, especially at the game's release in 2008, was a very small indie team. I still think the music is beautiful, even nostalgia aside. I recommend tracks like "Are You Coming Home, Love MOM," "Ode To The Bridge Builder," "The Goo Filled Hills," and "Tumbler" to see the wide range of styles this game covers. The soundtrack is free on Steam and easily accessible on youtube, Kyle Gabler's blog, and other platforms :)
Overall, World of Goo is an excellent puzzle game, an excellent indie game, and well worth it's low price tag. Please give this game a chance if you somehow haven't in the last decade.

86618824.review:
[h2]Briefly:[/h2]
There's fun to be had as long as you plan on ignoring the achievements, or if you enjoy achievements that require a punishing level of perfectionism to obtain. For me, that isn't the case.

[h2]More fully:[/h2]
The game [i]itself[/i] is good. It's decently creative and has personality, and the puzzles are challenging but solveable. So far so good.

But, if you're someone who bothers with achievements or otherwise cares about them, it becomes quickly frustrating. So, not so good.

Out of 8 achievements:
 - 1 is for passing the game
 - 1 is for doing something unusual on a specific level
 - The other 6 of are finnicky, nitpicky, perfectionist achievements only earned on passing [b]every[/b] level in a chapter with much more restrictive requirements (for which you get an "OCD flag")

It was this third point that soured the game for me. Because I do care about completing a reasonable percentage of achievements for each game I play (50-75% for most, unless I really like the game, then it's 75-100%). Unfortunately, these 6 achievements take a [i][b]disproportionate[/b][/i] amount of time [i]beyond[/i] simply playing the game decently well and passing it—and they make up 3/4 of the achievements obtainable.

It was after I spent hours in the the first chapter getting OCD flags for the first 10 levels (failing over and over on the 10th) that I started to ask myself why I was spending so much time at something I was coming to hate.

I realized that I was wasting my time and not enjoying myself, all for the sake of getting achievements in a game where the designers set them up in such a way that they punish the casual player.

I [i]might[/i] come back to it at some point and at least finish it, but it'll take a while for my distaste to fade.

82221714.review:
World of Goo Review

Ahh, this is probably the first video game I have ever played. EVER. I still remember the times where my cousin and I would play this game on his iPad (1st Gen), having so much fun. Remembering this, I gave World of Goo a shot, and boy howdy did I instantly fall in love with this game.

World of Goo is a physics game on building Goo structures to reach a certain goal. Usually, this is a pipe that you need to build to, but on the last levels of each world (there are 6, including the Epilogue and the World of Goo Headquarters), there is a different objective to advance the story line. The levels aren't overly difficult, they're just difficult enough to intrigue you, but not to rage-quit the game. I really enjoyed this game.

On every level (except the first), the Sign Painter (A.K.A. The Sign Writer, SignPaintr4evr, [spoiler]The Telescope Operator[/spoiler]) writes messages on signs. They can either give tips, advance the story line or simply be humorous. If I were being honest, I would not have been able to complete the game if it wasn't for this mysterious, funny and slightly creepy (he can see you even though his messages come in the form of SIGNS. Give me a break) man/woman that is the Sign Painter.

Every once in a while, you can encounter different types of Goo. Some worlds are completely based on that specific goo. One example is the Green (Ivy) Goo. These types of Goo have 3 attachment 'arms' and can detach from the Goo structure if you so wish to. In the words of the Sign Painter: '[i]Maybe they have commitment anxiety, I'm not sure, but it looks like they can be easily detached from each other.[/i]'

The story line completely revolves around one company: The World of Goo Company. This is the company responsible for controlling (not making) and modifying different types of Goo. Once you complete a certain amount of levels, you unlock a special world: The World of Goo Headquarters. This is where all your goo get placed when they go into the pipes. Once again, in the words of the Sign Painter: '[i]As you complete levels, the Goo Balls you collect are sent here. How nice to see them again! Though they seem to have lost their essence[/i].' The World of Goo Corporation refine the Goo into a special type of Goo before sending it into the world. The special Goo Balls (which I will call WOG Goo) are kind of a mix between the normal Goo and the Green Goo; they can detach from the structure, like the Green Goo, but they have similar colouring and the same amount of attachment arms as the normal Goo. In this world, you have only one goal: build UP (or do nothing). [spoiler]And you can totally obliterate the Headquarters near the end of the game.[/spoiler]

The story line is great. The animation and sprites are even more so, and the puzzles in the game are really clever and fun. 2D Boy did a great job with their games (they also made Little Inferno, the game which had the trailer that is scary, Human Resource Machine and 7 Billion Humans). I thoroughly enjoyed this game. If you want a puzzling but intriguing and fun gaming experience, why not play World of Goo?

80876265.review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

World of Goo is a Puzzle game developed by 2D Boy.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

The game is divided into 4 chapters and an epilogue, whereby each of the chapters uses a different scenery and therefore plays differently than the previous chapters. A bonus chapter actually planned for the European market has been postponed until further notice, as the game appeared earlier than planned. Within each level, a certain number of goos must be sucked in through a pipe from a given amount. This is done by connecting the goos together and, depending on the level, building a bridge towards this pipe, for example.

In the so-called tower-of-goo mode, the goos that have been collected too much in the course of the chapters can be assembled into a tower and compared with other players on the Internet.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ suitable for both hardcore and casual gamers
+ very varied puzzles
+ Chapters tell a story
+ easy to learn, difficult to master
+ simple controls
+ coherent atmosphere
+ Achievements and trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- could use more puzzles
- The choice of goo balls is sometimes a bit fiddly

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

World of Goo combines style and substance and also impresses with its wealth of variants. Clear buy recommendation.


[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

World of Goo ist ein Puzzle-Spiel, welches von 2D Boy entwickelt wurde. 

[h1] Gameplay / Geschichte [/h1]

Das Spiel ist in 4 Kapitel und einen Epilog unterteilt, wobei jedes der Kapitel eine andere Szenerie nutzt und sich daher anders als die vorangegangenen Kapitel spielt. Ein eigentlich für den europäischen Markt geplantes Bonuskapitel wird bis auf weiteres zurückgestellt, da das Spiel früher als geplant erschien. Innerhalb eines jeden Levels müssen aus einer vorgegebenen Menge an Goos eine bestimmte Anzahl durch ein Rohr eingesaugt werden. Dies geschieht, indem man die Goos miteinander verbindet und so je nach Level zum Beispiel eine Brücke in Richtung dieses Rohrs baut.

Im sogenannten Tower-of-Goo-Modus dürfen die im Laufe der Kapitel zu viel gesammelten Goos zu einem Turm zusammengebaut und im Internet mit anderen Spielern verglichen werden. 

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ sowohl für Hardcore- als auch Gelegenheitsspieler geeignet
+ sehr abwechslungsreiche Puzzles
+ Kapitel erzählen eine Geschichte
+ leicht zu lernen, schwer zu meistern
+ simple Steuerung
+ stimmige Atmosphäre
+ Errungenschaften und Trading Cards

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- könnte mehr Puzzles vertragen
- Auswahl der Goo- Bälle manchmal etwas fummelig

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

World of Goo verbindet Stil und Substanz, und beeindruckt auch durch sein Variantenreichtum. Klare Kaufempfehlung.

72885335.review:
World of Goo is a charming, challenging, and rewarding puzzle game with a lot going for it. It features 43 unique, original physics and skill based challenges that are likely to have you addicted enough to want to 100% the game. There's also a non-achievement competitive endgame engineering challenge where you can try to construct the highest tower possible with all the goo balls you've collected over the course of the game. 

The game's atmosphere is perfect, with solid overall direction including its quirky visuals and memorable soundtrack. This is one of my all time favourite puzzle games and I believe I've now fully completed it on every platform on which it's available, such is the lasting appeal. If you want to approach it casually, the standard completion criteria is well balanced. If you wanna come at this hardcore, the OCD completion criteria will drive you to perfection.

There are only a few very minor negative points. First, there are 1-2 semi-cheesy levels where the difficulty has a bit of an RNG component but I'd argue their inclusion is actually a good thing, because finishing them with OCD criteria is as cathartic as the challenge is frustrating. Second, there appears to be slight compression static on a few of the game's audio tracks.

72741649.review:
After completing the first four worlds, only about 5 of the levels had what I would consider any sort of puzzle aspect.  And for 3 of these 5, figuring out the puzzle is the secondary nature of the level.  The focus is just on stacking goos or figuring out what new goos do.  It's like calling Zelda a puzzle game because you get a new weapon and have to figure out how to use it to fight enemies.

This focus on stacking goos might be alright if the physics engine in the game made any sense.  But there are huge issues such as your stack suddenly breaking and folding in on itself, folding THROUGH other objects, even though the game is set in 2D space.  If its NOT in a 2D plane then your goo stacks should just fall over in or out of the screen at any height.  Maybe the game is just out of date. 

I couldn't bring myself to do the prologue as the first level is just another "try some random stuff - the objective isn't even on screen".  Honestly I'm not sure this game deserves a puzzle tag.

71290115.review:
Simple in design but can get complex very quickly. I was surprised how the early levels drew me in and enticed me to play more (although the game is definitely only as long as it needs to be). While this is a very interesting and unique physics game, I do have my issues with it.

-Some levels require quick reactions in order to solve, which rather goes against the whole tone of puzzle games for me. I prefer taking all the time I need to think and plan things out.

-Many levels don't even show you where the goal is or what you're supposed to do in absence of them. I'm not asking the game to hold my hand, but it would be nice to at least see the whole level so I can plan my solution out rather building blindly.

-Trying to get hold of a specific goo ball in a tight overcrowded structure is incredibly frustrating - a tab target switching ability might not go amiss.

-Finally, luck has an annoying presence especially if you're a completionist. In a genre that requires you to think outside the box to get the best results, RNGsus throwing a monkey wrench into the physics engine kind of hinders that.

71254522.review:
Much different than other indie games I've played so far, World of Goo is something that shouldn't be taken too seriously nor treated as the next big physics-based puzzle game. Although it's a really old title, the devs have decided to update it roughly a decade after its release for enhanced support for more modern systems. It did take awhile to setup as it's default to the OG 2008 version running in a stretched 800x600 resolution locked at 60fps, with the volume of the music too loud, mouse sensitivity too high, and overall image too dark and blurry. After though, one can render it up to 1920x1080 and beyond, disable v-sync and run at the highest framerates possible, listen to music that isn't deafening, and finally have moderately sensitive controls.

The art style alone is very immersive and appealing - I think it's what prevented me from raging at some of the confusing levels later on lol. Don't be deceived by the simplistic gameplay mechanics, it's quite challenging as making a few mistakes results in losing the level and the accuracy of the controls tends to be questionable; however, one can easily "rewind" some mistakes made as a feature, or they can simply restart and even skip the levels. All you have to do is place the goo balls from the beginning to the end for a pipe to suck up the required amount to progress through. Each level obviously changes it ever so slightly with new puzzles and obstacles to overcome, and some vague hints that are a bit helpful. There's only 5 worlds so this game is quite short and can be literally beaten within 5-10 hours, and the only extra game mode you have is to build the tallest goo ball tower as you can for bragging rights. 

Story is next to non-existent and I won't spoil it for you readers of course, and the levels individually can take a few seconds to a few minutes assuming no restarts are taken. Oh right, also the devs in the anniversary update added trading cards, wallpapers, and emojis if you're into that sort of thing which I kind of care about. The only achievements there are for those that strive to be completionists, so you won't unlock any achievements for simply doing basic or even intermmediate conditions. I highly discourage people from purchasing this game at full price and to only buy this during a major holiday sale as there are tons of other indie games similar priced that are more worth your while. I was originally going to give this game a mixed-negative review, but I've changed my mind and I'll realistically give this a thumbs up when it's still a bit neutral for me.

70202198.review:
This is a fun little physics-based puzzle game! Very minimal story, just a cute little post-apocalypse to tie the very bizarrely themed levels together. Basic premise is that you connect little goo balls together to build structures and avoid obstacles like fire or spikes to get to your goal. The challenge comes with limited materials, structural integrity issues, the ability to either reuse or permanently lose goo balls, flammability of goo balls, etc. The puzzles are on the medium difficulty. Usually figuring out what you need to do is the shortest step, and then it's just execution from there. Some of the end-of-level puzzles are much harder, but I feel that this isn't a bash-your-head-against-the-wall difficult game. Definitely a lot of restarting if you were focusing too much on stability and ran out of goo balls in the process. Sometimes you need to embrace the jank!

Overall, it's short, but with cute art, sounds, music, good level design, a lot of variety. Worth a few bucks for sure!

67981869.review:
World of Goo is a physics puzzle game where you control a collection of goo particles, and try to get them into a pipe. Building structures by connecting balls of goo together is how you get them to the finish pipe. The unused balls crawl along your structure, and then into the pipe to end each level.

The physics feel great. The unused balls of goo crawling along your structure have mass, not just the components of the structure. Shifting them around is the key to some puzzles. The structures never break from their own weight, only bend, which saves a lot of frustration. Gravity is consistent between levels, except for a short sequence of levels where unique gravity for the level is the main component of the puzzle.

The humor is excellent. Your adventure is narrated by a series of signs written by a character identified only as "the Sign Painter." Their exasperated/humorous narration of the goo traveling through the world lends a lot of charm to the world. The game is very self aware that it is a game, breaking the fourth wall multiple times, each time to great effect.

Puzzle design is good. Challenging at times, but very well designed. Each puzzle takes a few minutes at most to figure out a way to do it, with most having more than one solution. Much more time could be spent on this game than I spent if one wanted to optimize the levels.

There are multiple different types of goo balls introduced through the game, each of which interacts with the environment in a different way. Each one is interesting and unique, and does not overstay its welcome.

Overall, I would recommend this game. I did get it has part of a HumbleBundle, so not sure if I would by it on its own.

67839788.review:
World of Goo has two difficulty levels: easy and OCD. The easy mode is almost exclusively a boring exercise in bridge building that doesn't feel in any way mentally stimulating. 

The OCD mode is more about careful precision and time expended trying and re-trying for exactly the right set of physics situations - your bridge must be swinging just so, and the weight must be distributed just this way. 

The lack of any real middle ground between these two difficulties makes this game hardly worth the time investment. There are somewhere between 50 and 100 puzzles (im about halfway done the game as I'm writing this) and all of them have extremely strict conditions on what you can't do. You can't use special orbs in free play, either. There are a few gems here and there, but most of the puzzles feel relatively identical - build a bridge over the gap, or get into the tight space without touching the spikes.

67749201.review: Brilliant in more ways than one. Such intelligent psychics-based gameplay and an unforgettable visual style. This game came out in 2008, yeah this looks so unique and better than most AAA games not for its realism but the aesthetic. So many years ago I spent so long on this and coming back it's aged absolutely flawlessly.

67577876.review:
This is one of those games that every gamer should play through at least once in their life time.

It's everything a game should be. Simple to play, yet complex to master. A funny story, but without getting in the way. A focus on game play, not just showing off the latest hardware.

There is a balance to world of goo rarely seen in gaming these days. You can approach it purely for relaxation and put in minimal effort to move through the landscapes, or you can drive yourself insane trying to perfect the OCD tier challenges.

They even managed to put in a meta free-form puzzle that gets larger and more complex based on how well you do on the individual levels.

Maybe you won't put 100+ hours into this, but you could easily put 10+ and still want more.

Also note: I played this for years (bought it direct from the developer) before buying it again on Steam, so my hours here do not reflect the real amount of time I've put into it.

67087772.review:
I remember playing this game for hours when I was a child. I would stay up until hours after midnight, hoping to reach the next level. I was too young to understand the concept of physics, and thus never reached the end.

That was until, by accident, I came across the game in the steam store. Given it was on sale, I could not pass on playing this game once more and this time, reach the end with knowledge of physics. And oh man, was it worth it.
Puzzling with diverse goo-balls is quite more fun then you would expect

Pros:
- Unique, interesting story
- diverse, challenging levels
- the soundtrack: that nostalgia feel hit me like a bomb (the soundtrack is free on steam!)
- OCD (Obsessive Completion Distinction): (extremely difficult) challenges to keep you busy 

Cons:
- OCD's can be a pain: the game tends to rely more on RNG than on physics every now and then, so if you wanna complete them, expect high blood pressure most of the time (especially 4.2, man I almost broke my monitor 3 times in the span of 2 minutes) 
- In the first few levels, the moving balls can be a bit frustrating without the whistle

In short, I would totally recommend playing this game. Even if the OCD's made me more angry than I have ever been in my entire life, the game itself is so lovely and fun that I can't help but praise it.

6/10

World of Goo is truly a timeless legend. I remember first starting to play it back in 2009, when it was one of the best and most successful indie games at the time. Bought it later on steam, with an intention to show respect to the game and the crew.

The gameplay is simple and fairly easy once you understand the mechanics and know what to do next. However, some levels can be challenging in the first run (it's a puzzle game after all). After beating the game, the ultimate OCD challenges are also worth a try (especially if you don't even know what it is like me after the first run). 

What impressed me most was its epic soundtrack by [i] Kyle Gabler [/i] (which is free to download on his website) and unique art style. From the uplifting [i] Ode to the Bridge Builder [/i] to the epic and emotional [i] Best of Times[/i], the haunting melody showed me that music from a game can leave such an impression. Later on I learned that a deeper and darker meaning lies behind the fantasy story, which I wasn't actually a fan of but is magnificent anyways.

54846755.review:
I don't know how to describe this game other than "beautifully inventive". It's great, and well worth the money. The creators have done a great job integrating humor and meaning into this well thought out piece of art (I call this art because it's true). You will not find a more artistically enclined game app like this. It's fun, creative, and one of my favorites.

The object of this game is to drag goo balls to build a structure or two in order to get to the pipe which will sick the goo balls up. It has a story, but is more focused on the gameplay.

The gameplay is simple and you will get the hang of it in no time. It is challenging at times, but not so challenging that you will pull your hair out in frustration. I found that sometimes when I tried to pick up a certain goo ball, it wouldn't register correctly and pick up a different one. You can avoid this by zooming into the screen to make the goo balls appear larger.

The graphics are outstanding. It has sort of a Tim Burton style which I find very appealing. At one point the game will be very colorful and the next it would be dark and backlit. This, along with the breathtaking music in the background, sets the mood for every level.

Get this game. It is great, well worth $5. Though this game is short, you will enjoy every minute of it. I hope they make a sequel with more levels, but for now it is great; a little masterpiece.

52644606.review:
I tried to play this game ages ago on Steam and I didn’t get very far as physics puzzle games tend to be games I have the least patience with. I recently tried it again on my phone through the Humble Bundle app where I got this in a bundle years ago and I actually managed to complete it.

Honestly there was more to this than I originally thought. I had thought that this was a general physics puzzle game where you go stage by stage through a level map and you had some kind of “get 3 stars to complete each level 100%” kind of thing.
Those kind of games are alright, but generally I don’t enjoy them as I do tend to be someone who wants to complete each level 100% or “get all 3 stars”. Being a bit of a completionist like that I do end up frustrating myself, so me thinking that the game was like that, I think I put myself off playing it for a long time.

Although the game does have a higher level of completion, it’s not the “3 star” set up I thought it was. You can complete levels as normal, being able to move on as long as you have managed to solve it. The higher level of completion is an “OCD” goal, where you have to complete the level again but by collecting a certain amount of goo balls at the end of it.
Looking at it, it seems as if it makes the game a lot more challenging, but I chose not to even attempt the OCD goals as there were some difficult levels I barely even managed to scrape by completing.

The game also isn’t as flat as I thought it was in terms of story (or maybe more so moral). There isn’t a great masterful story or anything, but the game clearly has a moral lesson set in it which it brings out in the small bits of satirical dialogue that you read. 
I actually thought it was very witty at times and it brought a lovely charm to the game. It was quite a distinct and unique charm, which I also found in Little Inferno by the same developers.

Although I enjoyed the game, I’m glad that I completed this on my phone, as I have noticed the achievements for this game really would have frustrated me! The majority, it seems, being for completing entire chapters worth of OCD goals.

I’d definitely recommend this game, even though it feels as if it is hundreds of years old, and was probably among one of the first indie games around when indie games started to become popular. Despite its age, it’s still a great game.


TL;DR : A good challenging physics puzzle game that I played through on android. There is more to it than it seems, it's fun and a definite recommendation from me, although the Steam achievements look quite frustrating.

52417339.review:
It's a very fun and challenging puzzle game. The learning curve is spot-on and the game guides you through every mechanic.
Maybe the most important part is the message it transmits, though. Reading each of the messages in each level will guide you through the lore of the Universe and tell you the story about the World of Goo Corporation, and the dangers of excessive greed and amoral "progress". While telling this, it also does excellent critique of social issues like materialism and pollution.

Even though it doesn't detract from the main gameplay experience, it may add up for a totally different second gameplay. Definitely worth the buy!

50090378.review:
[u]In short:[/u] World of Goo is a physics-based bridge-and-tower-building puzzle game. With innovative gameplay, a distinct visual style and a great soundtrack it was groundbreaking when it originally released in 2008, especially considering the tiny team behind it. Putting away the nostalgia goggles, it sadly doesn't really hold up and its many frustrating flaws and shortcomings would be unacceptable for any current game. It is by no means terrible, but I can't bring myself to recommend it in 2019 either. I also consider the full price a bit too high, but on sale your milage may vary.

[u]In long:[/u] For the basic [b][u]gameplay[/u][/b] think bridge building simulator, but your materials are alive. An initial structure is teeming with tiny goo balls. Click-drag them to expand the structure towards the goal pipe, but don't use too many as sending a sufficient number down the pipe is the objective of the game. Gradually more types of goo balls introduce new mechanics like lift provided by balloons, reusable goo balls, flammable structures, etc. Sometimes you have to build a tower to reach the pipe, other times you have to bridge a chasm or an obstacle of deadly spinning blades. Some stages even have unique mechanics that diverge from the basic gameplay. With 49 levels across 5 worlds the game is short enough where it doesn't feel repetetive, but a few levels are so hard, that you will spend quite a long time bashing your head against a wall, which may get boring.
A word on the [b][u]difficulty[/u][/b]: The tutorialization is rather slim. There are some advanced tricks that are never explained, but greatly smoothe the experience (nudging of tower, throwing goo balls, etc.). There is a good amount of unpredictable randomness in how your goo balls move around and make everything wiggle and sway. There's a reason most puzzle-builders have a build-mode and a separate execution phase, so the outcomes are deterministic. Only some levels feature an undo functionality and it is very limited in scope. Usually a mistake means resetting the whole level. All in all it took me a little over 5 hours to beat the game, but I spent the majority of time on just ~6 of the harder levels. One of them was particularly nasty and frustrated me a lot. The difficulty generally ramps up, but varies wildly, even in later worlds. Beating all the levels is not trivial, but not incredibly demanding either.
That changes when we're talking about the [b][u]optional goals[/u][/b], which took me twice as long (around 11 hours). Every level has an additional target that will give you an "OCD flag". Questionable name aside, for about half the levels this actually requires perfection, while the other half allows for some leeway. There are three types of goals limiting you in time, amount of moves or amount of goo balls you can use. None of them are aided by the UI in any way (you don't see how many goo balls you have left and you don't get to see your time or your move count at all before finishing the level). There certainly is a skill component, but notably a few levels actually rely on dumb luck (usually your tower collapsing just in the right way to reach the goal) or on obscure cheese that is never explained anywhere. The game does encourage chasing the OCD goals (6 of the 8 Steam achievements are about OCD flags), but this hunt only serves to really highlight the game's many shortcomings:

Most notably the [b][u]interface is terrible[/u][/b]. Short of counting them manually you don't get to know how many goo balls you have and therefore how many you can use to still meet your goal quota. The goo balls will constantly move around unpredictably, which makes it almost impossible to select one in particular, which can cause you to fail a level in a time-critical situation when your tower might need support from a balloon, but you can only select the normal goo balls covering the balloons. Even worse when you want to deconstruct reusable goo balls, as they tend to get covered by any nearby goo ball. The incredibly minimalist UI certainly looks sleek, but it lacks in functionality. There are also no hotkeys for anything except Esc bringing up the in-game menu. On this menu "reset" is the top-most option (which resets your level without any additional confirmation prompt) and "resume" is the bottom-most. More than once did I accidentally reset my progress after returning to the game after a short pause.
The game also loves to [b][u]waste your time[/u][/b]. Every level has an introductory sequence slowly panning across the level. Many levels conclude with in-game or animated cutscenes. None of them are skippable. For some strange reason there is also no way to reset a level once the minimum goal has been met. These two together make the OCD grind absolutely excruciating. If you come up just one goo ball shy of the OCD goal you can't simply restart the level - you have to first finish it, watch the rating screen animation, potentially watch a cutscene of up to 90s length after the level, go back into the level and watch the level introduction cutscene again. When simply resetting a level takes over a minute I could feel my blood pressure rising. Between having to manually count moves, having to watch certain cutscenes literally dozens of times and fumbling to pick out certain goo balls in time-critical situations, clearing the OCD flags honestly felt like fighting the game/UI more than fighting the challenge of the levels.

The [b][u]presentation[/u][/b] is actually one of the strong-suits of this game. I very much enjoy the visual style. More the slick aesthetics in-game than the hand-drawn absurdist cutscenes, but they both fit and serve their purpose. The story is quite dark, but endearingly told with a good sense of humour. The sound effects are generally good and the music is actually amazing. It's great and very memorable, which sadly soured on me a bit during the OCD grind, when I would hear the same pieces over and over again.

On the [b][u]technical side[/u][/b] side we are back to substantial shortcomings. Windowed mode is default and works well, but you cannot adjust the very small resolution short of digging into .ini files. Alt+Enter apparently toggles full-screen but that just left me with a black screen with occasional brief flashes of light (might be my system's fault though). Part of the problem is that there is no settings menu whatsoever. That also means zero volume control, not even a simple option to mute the music. Sometimes the sound effects provide valuable clues (like goo balls dying, lighting on fire, etc.) so it's not wise to mute the game completely. But that also means the music will always be blasting in your ears, even when you replay certain levels dozens of times. For a 2019 title this frankly would be unacceptable and I'm hesitant to give it a pass just due to its age. I also rarely had a few issues with inputs (e.g. holding LMB should whistle to attract goo balls, but sometimes it just didn't).

In [b][u]conclusion[/u][/b] World of Goo certainly was groundbreaking in 2008. I still have fond memories of it and I appreciate the amazing feat for a tiny indie team of 2-3 people. But replaying through the game a few years ago I already felt most of the magic was gone. Going back to clear the OCD flags in 2019 really highlighted all the many flaws and frustrations for me. It frankly doesn't hold up anymore in 2019. Which means the full price of 10 bucks is pretty ambitious for a game you can finish in 5 hours which has this many flaws. If you have nostalgia for World of Goo, go for it, but if you've never played it, you should probably stay away or substantially lower your expectations.

47169050.review:
World of Goo wastes no time in establishing what might as well be its only mechanic, making a finite number of connective links between nodes of the titular ‘goo’ to reach an arbitrary goal while building around a number of  contrived obstacles and hazards - gameplay that the vast amount of players will have seen somewhere before from any number of rudimentary ’2D builder’ games before this one. 

What sets apart World of Goo from all others trying to ape this genre is how a handful of independent industry veterans have pooled their combined experience, talents, and vision to create a roughly three-to-four hour long experience brimming with artistic integrity. In a series of chapters that have remained so relevant since 2008 it begins to border on the prophetic, themes of corporate consolidation, petroleum usage, and social media datamining run throughout the plot as experienced by a collective of apparently sentient lumps of black-grey ooze that possess an almost-childlike innocent curiosity and cuteness about them despite being little more than blank circles with googly eyes. 

Across five highly-distinct chapters and a post-game sandbox area, you will get to experience gameplay that enjoys shaking up the fundamentals of the puzzle concept while never becoming obtuse. Each of the humorous story beats (best left unspoiled) works well in the cartoony artstyle and hand-drawn cutscenes and are perfectly underscored with a musical score tailored to each encounter in addition to the snippets of lose pseudo-lore provided courtesy of the enigmatic ‘Signpainter’ and mysterious ‘MOM’ figures - and more than one very well-hidden secret area.

World of Goo is the type of game that could be fired out over the course of one afternoon, but is the type of experience liable to sit on your mind for a quite a while - even if you aren’t an Achievement hunter seeking the ‘OCD’ (“obsessive completion distinction”) bonus objective awards - until you inexorably decide to return to this cozy, gooey, nook in indie gaming history. For newcomers to the game, swayed by this review or any number of the online testament to this title’s great content, it is a game that I will state you won’t regret taking in the unique atmosphere of.

Highly recommended.

44790411.review:
A short, but very sweet and melancholy game.  I have a lot of nostalgia for this game, as I played it back when it came out on the Wii Shop Channel in 2008.  The puzzles are very intuitive, and the art style and music has a very unique charm to it that isn't matched by any other indie game out there.

My only complaint with the game is the rewind system.  There will be times where you will come across difficult puzzles.  The only method of undoing your mistakes if you manage to break the level are these little 'Time Bugs' that fly across the map, that you click on to rewind a turn.  The only problem with these is that when you click one, it will rewind you to right when the last action has already happened, so the only way to rewind a significant portion of your turns is to click them rapidly, which wastes all of them.  It's extremely inefficient, and a tad frustrating.

Overall, World of Goo is an amazing game, and absolutely worth your time.

43896134.review:
World of Goo is a fun architectural puzzle game. The basic idea is that you have a limited number of various types of gooball and you need to use them to build a structure that reaches the exit pipe on each level with enough left over to meet the level's requirements. A lot of the levels mix up that formula to varying degrees, but that's the basic starting point. It's a good game, but if that doesn't sound like your kind of fun you probably won't like it.
As to what makes it a good game, the level design and the variety of gooballs keep things interesting while being presented well enough to not feel overwhelming, the difficulty is mostly in the sweet spot between boring and frustrating (and you're allowed to skip a few levels if you're really stuck and aren't feeling stubborn), the humor is goofy but entertaining, and the music and graphics are well-suited to the game.
The only downside is that it's short with only moderate replayability. My playthrough was probably a bit quicker because I'd played it most of the way through before and remembered a few solutions, but it only took me five hours. It'll probably take someone playing for the first time a little longer, and a good bit longer still if they want to get the achievements and complete the optional objectives and build a really huge tower in the World of Goo Corporation minigame.

43596888.review:
Classic case of a game that hasn't aged well. At all.

Perhaps I'm not the core demographic for physic puzzle games, but I distinctly remember finding games like Angry Birds or Cut the Rope more fun than this title.

The music is fine, graphics cartoonishly pleasing, and gameplay concept simple and effective. However, my main gripes come from the culmination of lackluster features that nearly all titles have nowadays, including recent puzzle games.

- Lack of music/volume/sfx menu 
- Inconsistency of move undo-ing for levels (It's there sometimes, not others, and often doesn't work the way it should)
- Screen is WAY too zoomed in, with no settings to change the window resolution
- The water physics are simply .... indescribable (It's near impossible to tell what's caused by your cursor or the objects themselves)
- Selecting goo balls that constantly move around make it easy for you to grab one you didn't intend, or worse, one that kept your structure up 
- Can't retry a level even if you complete the level unintentionally (OCD Achievement Hunters beware)
- Goo structures fall over each other in layers (Doens't make any sense to me why a structure is able to hang from itself)

[b] (Even though things like sound and screen resolution can be easily fixed with some file and mixer changes, it simply didn't improve the more apparent frustrations I had in the gameplay. So moreso, just a little insult to injury.)[/b]

Call me petty or downright stupid, but playing the same level over and over left me more frustrated than amused due to points such as these. [u]I'll appreciate the pioneering this game had done around a decade ago, but that doesn't mean it's the pinnacle iteration of puzzle games. I'd say it's best to leave the past behind on this one.[/u]

43532233.review:
A very Gooey-Bridge building puzzle game

The game involves you connecting goo-balls together to help them escape the stage. The concept has been done before but instead of making bridges with materials, you're making bridges with different types of goo-ball to traverse the various environments. Each chapter has a different setting each with a reason the goo-balls needs to saved. Almost each type of goo-ball has a different ability to help build your goo-made bridge. The soundtrack includes calm and soothing tracks while also having dark and creepy tracks for the more industrial stages. It is a shame it isn't purchasable on steam.

Overall, World of Goo is a creative change from the normal bridge building games. The Plot, Soundtrack and the Setting give the game a dark feel but with moments of success with saving the goo-balls from being turned into products.

41876646.review:
Let's face it: games like [i]World of Goo[/i] come a dime a dozen these days, and not just because its success has inspired a whole new genre. Physics-based bridge-builder-like puzzles are not rocket science.

However, [i]World of Goo[/i] was released in Blessed 2008; the year of [i]Braid[/i] and [i]Spelunky[/i]; the year indie games have drawn everyone's attention for the first time. And while [i]World of Goo[/i] is arguably less inventive than [i]Braid[/i] and less robust than [i]Spelunky[/i], it became one of the symbols of a new gaming era and won a lot of hearts over.

I do believe [i]World of Goo[/i] is the lesser of the three, but it still very much deserves its spotlight. The gameplay is fun, the visuals are cute, and the music is stunning. More importantly though, while the game isn't plot-heavy, it debuts Tomorrow Corporation's brand humor and charm. 

Half Burton, half Double Fine, it walks the precarious line belween cuteness and satire, often venturing into dark places with a straight face (all those blobs of goo you so often kill seem to be alive, after all). It's a mild comment on consumerism and corporations that's never too in-your-face and can be skipped if you'd rather just build bridges.

And hey, one more upside of small indie games is that they age well, so it plays perfectly ten years after its release.

40772285.review:
World of Good just didn’t do it for me. 

I couldn’t launch the game with dual monitors active. It would just flash the screen constantly until I disabled one. It also runs at a very low 800x600 resolution. You can change this in the config file but then text got cut off at the main menu. It just doesn’t handle widescreen very well. There are no in-game settings. 

I played up through the last level of the first world. You have to build structures out of goo balls in order to reach a pipe that sucks up the remaining goo balls. Each level has a different number you must save, each level varies and there are multiple types of goo. Sounds pretty decent but in reality it’s a nightmare. 

The biggest complaint are the wonky physics. You’re building soft structures that wiggle and move around. I could never predict what it was going to do and structures didn’t react to counterweights as expected. So you’re left frustrated level after level with no sense of learning. 

[b]Pros[/b]
+60fps
+Interesting concept
+Nice art style

[b]Cons[/b]
+Unpredictable physics
+Game doesn’t run with two monitors active
+Low resolution
+No game options

I don’t mind puzzle games, but this is outside my range of fun. 

[b]3/10[/b] Poor

From memory, I first played World of Goo in early 2009. I remember because it was only slightly before the time I played Plants vs Zombies for like 40 hours in high school. Plants vs Zombies pretty much took my undivided attention for a while there, and World of Goo got kinda left by the wayside. About 9 years later I give it another chance and I just can't see whatever magic there undoubtedly was for an indie physics puzzle game all that time ago. I certainly don't hate World of Goo; it's got charm and quality for sure. But it's also not particularly compelling or awe inspiring. 

If you love casual games or physics puzzle games then I'm sure you won't find much wrong with World of Goo. Since Steam reviews are about whether you would "recommend" the game, and not if you can recognize that some people would love the game - it's unfortunately a no from me.

39649078.review:
World of Goo feels like it's from another reality. Like your kitchen at 3 am or a highway with no cars.
When I was very little, when the Wii was released, the Wii was sent to my family as a gift. We downloaded the WOG Demo since it was free. It felt very strange to me. There was no sense of narrative (which a puzzle game like this doesn't need) but I was thoroughly spooked. The art style sends shivers, like a weird cross between Jacob Two Two and Invader Zim with some cartoonish charm thrown in. I don't think I ever beat the demo, and I certainly didn't buy the full game. It felt like buying the whole game would break some rule of reality.

Anyway fast forward to 201whenever and I obtained the full game through Humble Bundle.
I still get that eery feeling when I play, and I still haven't moved past the green hills, where the Demo began and ended.
If anything, the game got odder as it got older. The defunct multipler-esque elements of the free build zone really contribute to the abandoned world theme I'm pretty sure it was trying to portray. But really, I have no idea.

So what I'm trying to say is, World of Goo is my favorite horror game. Always scares me 10/10

(edit: updated in December because the show is called [i]Jacob[/i] Two Two, not Jonny)

37758034.review:
Ah, the gears of progress, watch them as they turn
The gears of 2D Boy's mind, smell them as they burn.
- The Type Writer

[u]Summary[/u]
World of Goo is a simple yet innovative Puzzle-based game where you help colonies of Goo Balls find their purpose in the universe.
Each puzzle involves using the Goo Balls to create structures and reach a pipe.
Each Goo Ball species has its own unique abilities and each puzzle has its own theme.
The player wins when when a certain number of Goo Balls go through the pipe.
In addition, each puzzle also has an OCD bonus that require the player to complete the puzzle within a certain number of moves, an allotted time, or by collecting extra Goo Balls.

[u]Features[/u]
Since this game is so simplistic, there's nothing really "wrong" to say about it.
The only issue I had was that it could've been longer or more fleshed out.
I was also disappointed with the Tower of Goo minigame, which you can play by collecting extra Goo Balls, since all it gives you are bragging rights for building the tallest Tower of Goo.

The story itself is... interesting, to say the least since it has no basic structure.
There IS a story, which centers around the Goo Balls trying to destroy the World of Goo Corporation after it conquers the world by using them as ingredients for commercial products.
Of course, you wouldn't know that from playing the game since there are no main characters.

Aside from the Goo Balls, which are so cute when they wake up, there are ten characters the player encounters throughout the game.
However, only two progress the storyline while the rest are exclusive to certain puzzles.
The first is the Sign Painter who gives advice for each puzzle and narrates the story.
The second is MOM who is a mysterious entity that the player eventually meets in Chapter 4.

[u]Conclusion[/u]
It's definitely a fun game to play, especially since the Goo Balls cameo in several other games.
Of course, if you're looking for a story or some form of immersion, you won't find it here.
World of Goo is one of those games where you play for the sake of playing.
So go ahead and make a mess, it's only a game.

36483353.review:
World of Goo, despite going nowhere, manages to go to places you wouldn't expect.

Ultimately, despite some small nagging problems, I liked World of Goo quite a bit.  The music was great (seriously), the atmosphere was foreboding (also seriously), and the game was often both challenging and interesting.  It's not the only physics based puzzle game out there, but it's a good one nonetheless.

However, World of Goo is really much more of a challenge game than a pure puzzle game, and here is where it's problems arise, the most damning of which is it's use of APM as a measure of difficulty. 

For those unaware, APM--Actions Per Minute--is, in so many words, a measure of how quickly someone can do something, usually on the computer.  It works similarly to WPM, or words per minute.  

There are several puzzles in World of Goo, which is already a fairly short game, that use APM as it's entire gimmick.  What I mean by that is, instead of a having a puzzle to actually solve, the challenge is to just be fast, either in part or in whole.

This is not an unusual design choice, nor is it an inherently bad one, but it's one that I feel doesn't fit the idea of a puzzle game, and the puzzles in World of Good that specifically rely on design are the ones that feel the weakest, and offer the most opportunity for frustration.  

Other issues like poorly explained puzzles, or just being unable to select the correct slime out of the dozens milling about your screen, among others, can occassionally sour the experience of a particular challenge.  That being said, this feeling rarely lasted for long for me.  

Still, my experience with the game was mostly positive, and there are some particularly outstanding (in my opinion) puzzles sprinkled in that more than make up for the duds.

For myself, I give World of Goo a thumbs up.  However, for puzzle purists out there, or for someone who has concerns over the physical ability to complete some of the puzzles, your money might be spent somewhere else.

-Amazing soundtrack

33339673.review:
World of Goo is a strange sort of puzzle game. Its gameplay mechanics are based on structural physics, involving lots of little balls of Goo that you can use in different ways. 

Everything about this game is well made. To me, perhaps the most accomplished of all is the developers' theme of combatting a corporate soullessness with tiny cogs of construction, in the form of the Goo. The minimalist story brings a smile and gives gamers a critical eye on consumerism while maintaining a light and fun gameplay. 

Also, props to the music. 

If you like puzzlers and haven't played this game, you should really try it out.

31507432.review:
So let me start off by saying this game is excellent, except for one incredibly major flaw. I love the level design, I think the concepts are fun, the physics engine is great, the story line is interesting, the cut scenes are wacky and neat, the dialog from the painter is well written, the sound effects are tremendous and don’t get old, the art  is a lovely stylized, it’s funny and I love this game.

Now for the one incredible unabashedly enormous flaw: I want to create the world’s largest Tower and the game caps the free mode or “Memorial tower” at 300 units. Of course, I understand why: The game designers don’t want cheating in online scoreboards, they don’t want to stress out your hardware, and it’s a smart decision from their perspective.

Now, here’s my rebuttal: Give me a serous warning label and let me do what I want. Maybe someone who is playing a game about stacking squealing goo isn’t someone who wants to spend his time in the most practical and intelligent manner. Maybe I want to crush my hardware’s processing power like a 400 pound baboon sitting on a wicker basket. Maybe I want to earn all the goo balls I possibly can and use my hard won units to create the most appalling insult to the heavens ever conceptualized. Maybe I want to laugh maniacally as my 100+ hours monument to stupidity scrapes clouds and the outer reaches of space and collapses in a stupid heap because of my poor architectural design choices.

Maybe that’s how I want to unwind and I can’t because the game creators don’t want me too and that makes me sad. 2D Boy game Studio you get an 8/10 from me but I will give you a 10/10 if you just let me do the one thing.

31279434.review:
This analogy is probably going to get lost on 99% of users here, but I feel like it'll be helpful for the 1% that does: back in 4th or 5th grade, we did something called the Bridge Project where we had to play this bridge building game as a sort of engineering exercise. Basically, you had to create a stable bridge while trying to balance costs.

World of Goo is essentially a puzzle game version of that. Here, you use sticky goo balls to create structures that get you to each level's end goal (a pipe that sucks up unused goos). The main obstacle here is physics, as you need to keep your structures from toppling over. There's a sort of built in comedy to watching all the ways your creations just topple in on themselves. And conversely, there's a huge sense of satisfaction when you actually complete a puzzle. It's not just that you've figured out an answer; you've used your ingenuity to build a unique solution.

The controls are unfortunately a bit of a hindrance here. It's often difficult to grab a goo without the cursor selecting one near it instead. This can lead to some frustrating moments where you accidentally destroy an entire level's work with one tug. Some of the game's more satirical humor doesn't quite work either. There's an anti-corporation theme throughout the story, but it's not really cohesive or well delivered enough to work. It comes off as being snarky without any real bite (I've never played Little Inferno, but from what I understand, that satire is built into the mechanics. Here, it's just sort of superimposed onto a puzzle game). 

Those gripes aside, World of Goo's mix of construction and puzzles is still incredibly unique all these years later. It's an essential game for fans of the genre.

(Note: I received this game as a gift from a friend.)

30483368.review:
I never thought I'd recommend an engineering game for the story, but here we are. 
World of Goo owes a lot to how well it executes on its aesthetic. The intrepid soundtrack coupled with a narrative that promises answers just over the next ridge contextualizes this game as one of exploration and discovery instead of just construction and puzzle solving. The goo balls themselves are simple but surprisingly lovable, and the mysterious Sign Painter brilliantly combines context, hints, and humor making these necessities of function into friends that are joining you for a journey into the unknown. It really is fascinating how the tone these elements create makes for a totally different game than what it appears to be mechanically. 
Ironically, the 'living building materials' gimmick that gives this game so much personality is also its most obnoxious quality. Once the goo balls make contact with a structure and awaken, they never stop moving. They constantly pulse around the structure both changing its weight distribution and making the selection of an individual goo ball difficult. This becomes a real problem as the goo balls become more diverse in nature, and timing becomes more of an issue due to the need for increasingly unstable structures. Introducing a 'whistle' mechanic in the second of the five chapters seems to have been done to solve this as it draws the goo balls to wherever you're clicking. But, in my experience, it only sped up their movement with a slight preference towards the vicinity of the whistling. The ability to pause and select a ball would have solved this issue, however it also would have taken away from the 'grand adventure' atmosphere that makes World of Goo the joy it is. 
So I suppose it's best to accept the frustration caused by their incessant fidgeting as a quirk of rather than a flaw, even if that does make the OCD extra challenges even more insanity-inducing than they would be without it.
