My 30 minute experience: I load into the game and notice the awful resolution as soon as I start the game. Not worrying about it, I let the game get to the main menu so I could change the resolution. The main menu pops up, and there are no options. You can't lower the ingame volume or change the resolutions. This game is pretty loud, so I had to turn down my system so that I didn't blow out my eardrums. Then came the gameplay. All you have to do is build structures to get to the pipe. That's all you have to do. A simple concept, and an easy game. As soon as you get started though, the game becomes increasingly difficult. The puzzles are all the same, but the physics are impossible to figure out. You could build straight up, putting the proper braces where they should go, and still have it fall over, because nothing sits still. The little goo's that you have to use to build are constantly moving to where the end of the tower is. This makes the top (or the side) of your tower very heavy. That causes the game to get very hard very quickly. It was a constant battle between the game and I. 

This game could be better, but it is a game that would be fun to play on sites like Kongregate.com or armorgames.com. I did not like it and I won't be playing it again. 4/10

28978367.review:
Juego de puzzles, donde tienes que unir cada Goo, mínimo junto a otros dos Goos, para que se conecten y vayan formando una red donde otros Goos puedan moverse, y avanzar hacia su destino final. La tubería.

Hay más de un tipo de Goo. En los primeros niveles te encontrarás Goos verdes, y Goos negros. Cada uno tiene una función un poco diferente. Se parecen, pero los verdes son reutilizables.

No sólo hay Goos en éste juego. También aparecen esferas redondas rojas, que cuando las conectas a un Goo, resulta que son globos, haciendo que el Goo que conecta quede más elevado y se mantenga más alto.

No voy ni por la mitad del juego, pero ya puedo decir claramente, que el juego se merece la fama que tenía, y tiene. És un juego muy minimalista. Ha cuidado y mimado cada detalle visual, para que sea super entretenido jugar y jugar sin cansarte del juego, a no ser que lleves un rato sin pasarte un nivel o puzzle.

Visualmente y musicalmente es una delicia. Los puzzles están bien hechos. Son variados. Las físicas funcionan muy bien. No és un juego fácil.

Lo recomiendo totalmente, si ya tienes algún juego de puzzles, te gustan, y quieres más. Una joya.

28723150.review:
[b][u]TO SUM UP:[/u][/b] Whether you like games that force you to think a bit while playing them or whether you'd just like to experience an undying classic of independent gaming, [b]World of Goo[/b] is the right place to go. So do not hesitate for a second. Just buy it.

[b][u]FULL REVIEW:[/u][/b] First of all, let me state this: [b]World of Goo[/b] is a classic among indie games. 2D BOY, the studio responsible for its creation, has crafted something incredibly imaginative, fascinatingly fun and spectacularly simplistic back in 2008. World of Goo is, simply put, one of the most unique and enjoyable experiences one can have. The gameplay is easy-to-learn yet utterly adictive. (And for all the completionists out there, you'll be pleasantly surprised to discover that the achievements are rather hard to obtain.) The game's design is eternally elegant, the graphics are glorious and – what surprised me even more – the story is staggeringly thoughtful, drawing numerous parallels  between our world and, you guessed it, the world of goo. If you reflect on what is being said (or rather being written by the "Sign Painter") it is positively possible that the game will leave you in a state of peculiar wonder. That, and many other of its aspects only further prove one very important thing: that World of Goo has aged incredibly well.

One of the best indie games ever created.
I remember playing and finishing it back in 2008, saw it was on discount so I bought it on steam too.
World of Goo is a building puzzle game, you make structures using "Goo" with the goal to reach a pipe at the end of each level. It offers a lot of fun and a good challenge, each level has an optional "OCD" goal aswell which is very challenging, so good luck getting them all. Finaly, a sandbox mode with all the aditional goo balls you managed to save.
The art style is very good and doesn't show it's age at all. Excelent music.
The only cons i can think of is that it has no in game options for resolution or sound, personaly I never had any trouble with that, but you should know.
What are you waiting for? Get it!

28297795.review:
Amazing puzzle game, basically this game is a legend, it's hard to find any gamer 20+ years old who haven't played/heard about that game. Only 80Mbs heavy, this game provides high-quality graphics (for 10 years ago it was like 10/10) and very nice physics puzzle game. So:

+Visuals: From the visual point of view this game is great, all the surroundings, various goo balls, and *NPCs* looks very nice. Yet this game has its flaws - you can see on the store picture - 5th anniversary, yet this game is like 10 years old, it doesn't even have settings for visuals, and maximum resolution for this game is like 800x600, so on big screens, it will look pretty soapy and pixelated. Yet it looks nice FOR ME, and I have no problem playing it full screen stretched or windowed (alt+enter).

+Sound work: Amazing OST and funny goo balls sound, what else do you need?

+Gameplay: Plenty of puzzle levels with the breathtaking story, easy enough to simply complete the game and frustratingly hard to get all levels OCD complete thus...
...Steam achievements: there are steam achievements but they are really hard, you have to perfect every single level, and in addition to general puzzle difficulty you have your balls moving all the time, and your contractions shaking non-stop, so it adds an element of random to your actions, thus multiplying the difficulty.

+After completing all the levels you can build the highest tower among all the players, using additional balls you saved by perfecting levels.

TL;DR: This game is great, don't hesitate to grab it if you see it on sale or in some bundle if you haven't played it before.

Essentially World of Goo is kind of odd puzzle game where solve the puzzles by building bridges and towers out of goo. 

World of Goo is now eight years old and it's still fun, though of course not as addictive as first time around. 

Small part of the game is broken as online rankings don't work anymore. But that's minor issue in single player game. 

Few of the things that make World of Goo fun is difficulty level is pretty fair most of the time. Puzzles require some thinking, but don't require looking for walktrough, until few times towards the end. 

Also level design is good as game throws new things in frequently enough to keep things interesting.

If you still haven't played it, it's well worth the price.

This game was...fun. A fun little distraction with an interesting little background story that was tongue-in-cheek about it's slightly dark nature. It reminded me a lot of 'Little Inferno'; story-wise. The puzzle are engaging. Nothing too difficult; though if you're going for the OCD achievements you'll find enough of a challenge. The mechanics are simple enough: Just build up your balls of goo to create chains to try and reach the exit. Building them up in a manner that uses the least amount possible is the tricky bit. 

But I do suggest this game: Fun little thing that's a good little distractor.

26195021.review:
I'll be honest this is game doesn't scream for your attention to play it like a triple A title does; probably because you got it for $1 or it simply seems to small and limited in what it can offer. To a degree you'd be correct.

That being said it oozes (literally) with charm and good feelings. The game has that Nintendo mindset. It is easy to finish the levels all but the last 3. However achieving the OCD badge in all or ANY levels is an entirely different story; just like Nintendo. Aka easy to learn hard to master.

I 100%'ed the game I never felt any of the OCD challenges within the levels were outright unfair.

It took me 5 years to finally give this very charming game my attention, but honestly I'm glad i did.

4/5  

1 point reduction for length of the game regardless of price 3hrs of content (not including OCD) is simply not enough.

26095931.review:
Wow, I can't believe that this game is already 8 years old...

I originally discovered this game in a very unique way. In 2008, I was homeschooled, and we bought a computer for me to use with the schooling program. As the studious little boy I was, I searched on the computer (which was not connected to the internet) for ways to procrastinate, and one item I found was a compilation of hundreds of game demos, which would allow a limited amount of times that you could open it, 2-3 times I think. While playing the many games that were offered, I eventually stumbled upon this one, and I was drawn to it. I did everything I could to be able to continue to play it, including keeping it open for days, on end, and even creating new profiles on the computer to open it again (loophole!). Eventually, I finished all I could with the demo, with all of the levels of Goo Filled Hills beaten with OCD, and the highest tower I could build completed, I set it away the game and forgot about it.

4 years later, in 2012, I was given a Nook tablet to use for school, and one day as I was browsing through the apps, I saw this game on the app store, and bought and downloaded it as fast as I could. I played the game for hours, working to build a higher tower, or just beat that next level with OCD, and I can safely say, this is a game that I will never become bored of. A few more years later, I became more interested in video games, I downloaded steam, and discovered and bought this game straight away, both for my personal enjoyment, and for the support of the developers of this amazing game. 

Alright, enough about me, lets get to the review!

World of Goo is a game where you build towers and structures with goo balls to reach a pipe with a certain amount of goo balls left to be sucked up by it. The challenges begin simple, but as you progress you face more difficult and unique obstacles. This game also contains one of if not the most beautiful soundtrack in all video games, with fitting music for each level. The visuals and graphics of the game are very nice, and it runs very smoothly, even on lower end computers. Finally, the story is very interesting and creative, and it ties the game together beautifully. I highly recommend you play this game!

25155378.review:
Oh man, World of Goo. 

This game is a relic of fantastic game design. 

To put things simply, this game puts you in a world requiring you to build builds and complex constructs to overcome obstacles and reach the end. The end result uses encompasses your construct allowing your "goos" to reach the end pipe, with plenty of spare and win.
While super simple, this game can be frustratingly hard to beat. But once you beat the level, you are overwhelmed with a feeling of accomplishment. On top of beating the level, you can do what is known as an "OCD" challenge. Typically these result in a time trial, overabundance of goos or the least amount of moves possible. 

This game's physics constantly challenge you and require you to use your own intuition and reasoning to beat the level.

Overall, I HIGHLY recommend this game. It is cute, has an engaging storyline (which I won't spoil), and has the best engine for a physics-based puzzle game I've ever played. 

For anyone that wishes to see gameplay before buying, please check out my videos below:

A fantastic physics-based puzzle game in which you must help the Goo balls build a structure in order to reach the exit pipe for each level. It might sound simple at first, but as the game progresses and more and more species of Goo balls show up, along with more and more obstacles, the complexity increases. 23298553.review:
It's a fun game. It's got a lot of puzzle variety and a pretty good amount of content. But it's so bare bones in certain areas that I was absolutely convinced it was a poorly done mobile port until somebody corrected me.

What am I talking about? Dispite being a PC game first, it has no options menu of any kind, you can't correct the resolution, change the graphics (though I doubt you would need to) or even do something as simple as change the game volume. Distinguishing between the balls must be hell if you're colorblind, a menu option for that would have been really helpful for a lot of people. It does not lock the mouse to one screen if you have multiple monitors, but still requires that you move your mouse to the edge of the screen in order to pan the camera. It has no keyboard controls, even though it could have direly used some, such as the ablity to pan the camera with the arrow keys which would have delt with the mouse not locking issue, and a key for undo which would remove the need to click those stupid bugs (or more often, accidentally click one when you're trying to do a quick action).

Did I like it? I kept playing through the problems and beat it, so yeah I must have liked it dispite its problems. At the same time, would I recommend it? no, especially not at the normal $10 price tag. I found the missing features made it feel very unpolished and at the price point there are a lot of better games. Maybe on sale I'd recommend it, but that isn't an option.

22883010.review:
To hear the full review, listen to the episode on [url=https://soundcloud.com/gamehoard/episode-19-world-of-goo]Game Hoard Podcast[/url]

[b]Gameplay[/b]

World of Goo is a 2D physics-based puzzler with gameplay that revolves around building structures out of "goo balls" in order to reach a pipe at the end of stage. While this is a relatively simple set up for a puzzle game, the way in which the developers build upon it and create puzzle is ingenious. There are constantly new elements being introduced, from goo balls that can be detached or float, to environmental obstacles that may interact differently with different types of goo.

Going along with this, the challenges vary greatly. While the end goal is always the same, the level design means that different levels require totally different strategies. One level may require you to build the tallest tower you can while another may require you to build a small mobile structure while avoiding saws or fire. Another may have you selectively sacrifice some of your goo. This combination of different elements and challenges means that the game never once gets stale or boring. Each level feels wholly unique and the steady progression of difficulty and complexity is finely tuned. I found myself playing World of Goo for much longer sessions than I set out to. One important aspect of this is "time bugs" which allow you to go back in time by just a single goo ball placement. This means that you don't have to restart a whole level every time your structure fails and keeps the game from ever getting frustrating.

[b]Graphics[/b]

World of Goo is a real joy to look at. The game a sort of off-kilter cute but twisted look that is not unlike something in a Tim Burton film. It's a unique aesthetic that I personally enjoyed.

More importantly, the visuals inform the gameplay in important ways. All gooballs and obstacles look very distinct and little details give you clues about your environment, like leaves blowing around giving you an idea of the wind speed and its effect on your structure. The result is a game that is very easy to understand and interpret, allowing you to simply focus on the task at hand.

[b]Sound Design[/b]

In a word: excellent. The game features a variety of different tracks with some pretty great orchestral scores. I found that this music really set the tone of each level and left me feeling surprisingly exhilarated for as methodical as the gameplay actually is.

The sound effects are also great, with many sounds that are simultaneously cute, funny, and gross.

[b]Story[/b]

The story of World of Goo is very vague and centers around the world-dominating World of Goo Corporation which harvest gooballs to make a variety of products. While it's never clear exactly what is going on, the story goes through themes of oppression, environmentalism, vanity, rebellion, etc. in an effective way. It exists more to evoke a certain emotion than tell a compelling narrative and, when combined with the music and visuals, is very effective in that.

[b]Overall[/b]

Every aspect of World of Goo works and, more importantly, they all work perfectly together. It's a near perfect example of an indie game and there is good reason for it to be considered a classic. If for some reason you haven't played World of Goo, I whole-heartedly recommend it.

22261186.review:
World of Goo is a masterpiece of design.  Everything about this physics-based puzzler fills you with that grand feeling you used to have, back when you were 10 years old, playing in the yard. That feeling of Adventure.
The game starts very simply. Here are a bunch of cute quirky goo balls, and there’s a pipe up above them.  They make little squeals and pops when you click and drag them.  As you experiment with the balls, you learn how to build a tower out of them, yearning to reach that pipe. Where does it go? That’s a secret. Soon you’re building bridges, and balancing on ropes.  You come across species of goo that behave slightly differently, and let you interact with and build crazy new goo-based architecture, all in an effort to reach a pipe that’s just over there.  For instance, green goo balls can be removed from the structure and replaced, letting your structure climb up trees or snake through tight spaces.  But the difficulty never gets overwhelming. The learning curve here is expertly controlled, to where each level builds on the last. You are never forced to learn something in a totally new situation, not without a little gentle guidance from the invisible Sign Painter. The game seems to say “OK, you understand the basic dynamics here, but what if we do this?” The game adds a simple wrinkle you can immediately understand.  And you will eagerly jump in trying to solve it.
That eagerness will be due in no small part to the music. You can get the whole soundtrack for free right here.  The combination of whimsy and epic just fills you with that sense of Adventure and, honestly, it will just make you happy.
The visuals here are top notch. The cartoony, Dr. Seussical aesthetic serves the game’s atmosphere well, and each level feels very distinct. One early level makes the entire foreground, goo balls and all, completely black, while the background is a brilliant fiery sunset.  Truly a work of art.  Everything is clear and responsive, and behaves as expected.  One minor complaint is that when there are many goo balls in one area, it is difficult to select exactly the one you want.  This is a minor problem in the later levels, when you have 3 or 4 different types of balls and you’re on a time limit to finish your move.
The game is divided into 4 distinct chapters, each focusing on one season of the goo balls’ journey.  There is plenty to do here, but if you think the game is too short then each level has an OCD criteria (Obsessive Completion Distinction) which challenges you to solve it with a certain number of rescued goos, or within a set time or moves limit.  Going after the OCD achievements was a really good challenge! They force you to take your skills and knowledge of the physics systems to their absolute limit.
World of Goo was one of the first mega-hit indie games when it came out in 2008, and its success laid the path to the golden age of gaming we are enjoying today.  When my daughter is old enough to start playing mouse-and-keyboard games, this will be one of her first.  I recommend this game to anyone, for it is an important piece of gaming history, and it’s an amazingly fun Adventure.

21798560.review:
[h1]World Of Goo[/h1]

This review was last edited when I had completed the game.

[h1]Short Review[/h1]

An relaxing, casual physics puzzle game that has that "just one more go" attribute about it.

[h1]Long Review[/h1]

I have a confession to make. When I first played this game it just didn't grab me and I almost gave up the second time too but fortunately I stuck with it and was rewarded with a very enjoyable puzzle game that whilst not too taxing is hard enough to usually require several attempts to complete each level.

The game is actually quite difficult to describe but the best way I can describe it is to say you have a fixed number of goo balls that you can attach together to form a web like lattice that you can then use to transport the goo balls from one place to another. The idea is that you have enough goo balls left when you reach your destination to meet the level completion criteria.

There are different types of goo balls; the main ones can be attached together to form the web; some have no special function other than to count towards the count at the end of the level; some can only be shot into the air from the point you grab them; some float and can be used to lift the lattice into the air and others can catch fire etc.

The levels are relatively short; I generally finished each one in around 5-10 minutes (not counting re-attempts if I failed). There is a handy restart button to restart a level if you realise things are going pear shaped and you won't be able to complete a level. You can also click on the flies buzzing around to redo a move but top be honest I found this facility next to useless.

Hints are available by clicking on signs that also provide the game narrative. The hints tended to be pretty cryptic but occasionally very useful. The game narrative was a bit surreal for me ..

There is an excellent, unobstrusive soundtrack to the game.

There are 4 chapters & and epilogue to complete, each containing multiple levels. You have to finish one chapter to move onto the next but can replay any level you have previously completed.

It's possible replay value is in going back and redoing the levels faster or with more goo balls left over or to complete in OCD, which I think basically means you complete at maximum efficiency. I only managed this a handful of times

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*]Addictive, one more go type game ..
[*]Short levels
[*]No time pressures, you can take as long as you like to complete a level
[/list]
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]Took a while to grab me
[*]Can only be played in full screen
[*]When the game fires up it re-arranges my other open windows on my multi-monitor display
[*]The scrolling is very clunky. It requires the cursor to be moved to the edge of the screen and I found the cursor too easily leaves the game and appears on my second monitor
[*]Clicking on the flies to take back one move is next to useless. If I made a mistake this usually meant re-doing the entire screen again.
[*]There was a point about midway in the game where a few levels became tedious to complete as often the "critical" bit of the puzzle was quite a way into the puzzle meaning if you get that bit wrong you have to redo what quickly became the  boring bit of the puzzle several times
[*]In levels where you had several different goo balls available to was very difficult to pick the correct type which again at critical times became just plain annoying
[/list]
[h1]Marks Out Of 5[/h1]

5) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this
[h1]4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase[/h1]
3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted
2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted
1) Not worth getting even if given away free

[h1]Where I got the game from[/h1]

I won this game at [url=http://www.steamgifts.com/] Steam Gifts [/url]

[h1]Platform Played On[/h1]

Intel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, EasyAcc Mouse. 

[h1]My best guess for a PEGI rating[/h1]

Using [url=http://www.pegi.info/en/index/id/33/] PEGI Ratings [/url] I would rate this as a 3

19949012.review:
___/World Of Goo\___
Drag and drop a variety of squeaking, sticky goo-balls to fabricate structures than can be complex, magnificent or grotesque to get your goo-balls across endless chasms, spiky sawblades and slimy pools and into the end-point of each level, a collection tube that satisfyingly hoovers up your goo-balls and spits out your score based on the volume of adorable slimy spheres you have saved.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
>Well-crafted challenges, many unique mechanics are thrown at you in the latter stages. Doesn't get frustating.

>Runs at a low resolution, doesn't look crisp or sharp. The aesthetic and design is eccentric and definitely unique.

>Music sets the mood very well and provides helpful cues. Every little goo-ball makes a distinct sound that makes them lovable personalities that you'll love to watch bouncing around.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

You will definitely get a few solid hours of excellent puzzle gameplay. The game can suck you in for hours, but doesn't take very long to complete.

19747859.review:
[h1]Get it on mobile, PC controls are awful.[/h1]

The style is good but the game feels bad (at least on PC). No zoom, mouse to edges to move camera, and inconsistent connections (but that last one is probably just me being bad). These simple things, at least the first two problems, make the game an unnecessary struggle. It just seems lazy that they left the controls so poor. It also seems to have problem with multi-monitors (or maybe monitor resolution) but that can be fixed by modifying the config file’s resolution settings in the install location. I enjoyed it well enough on mobile so if you really want to play it you should get the mobile version rather than this version.

[b]Controls Cont:[/b]
If you are just reading this with no other context these problems may not seem that bad to you so I'll try to give you some insight. Some levels are just too zoomed in. You only get to see a small part of the screen at a time which means you have to move around and sometimes place goo at the same time. If you could move the camera with the keyboard then this might not be so bad but to move the camera you have to move your mouse to the edge of the screen. This means you can no longer place goo (unless the goo you are placing happen to also be on the edge of the screen you are scrolling with).

19270005.review:
A Good puzzle type game involving structure creation.

[h1]Tl;dr:[/h1]
buy it on sale if you like this type of stuff and don't mind lack of options menu.

[h1]Short Review:[/h1]
Pros:
*Interesting and various puzzles, which require planning, timing and (sometimes) speed.
*Ability to skip levels (limited, but can be increased by completing levels). 
*Artstyle's great.
*Different environments and types of Goo.
*Sountrack is beautiful and fits perfectly.
*Writing is witty.
*Simple, but enjoyable story.

Cons:
*Options menu? lol, nope. There are no resolution options, no different sound sliders, no ability to disable level cutscenes (yes they are short, but become slightly irritating after a while).
*Menu look ok (it is just icons), but it is not functional and lacks in features: options menu, credits.
*No user created content.
*Sandbox is pretty limited (one (basic) type of Goo).

Other notes:
*Lack of basic game elements (options menu, sandbox and user creativity limitations) really disappointed me.
*Do I recommend buying this on full price? Yes, if you have enough income and interest in this type of games.
*Do I recommend buying this on sale? Yes, of course (if you like puzzle games ;-) ).

18160957.review:
[h1]A creative and fun puzzle game that makes you think carefully about physics[/h1]

I've actually logged more hours in the Android version of the game than the PC version, but I believe the two versions are identical. 

You start every level with a lot of black goo balls. You have to connect them into a grid-like structure, expanding that structure until it's able to touch the exit point. You also need to have at least several goo balls remain unused (each level specifies the minimum) so that they can "escape" into the exit. 

This game can really make you rage at times (please do not smash your phone/tablet if you are playing on a mobile device). You can have a seemingly perfect, elegant structure that suddenly collapses because you didn't keep track of the weight on the upper portions. However, it is easy to revert your mistakes, and when you do fail you never feel that it was unfair - it's a great learning experience for your next attempt. 

I highly recommend this game as a casual time killer at the train station or the airport lounge. If you're like me and don't really touch these games very much on the PC, support the devs via Google Play, the Humble Android Bundle, the Apple App Store, etc.

17261587.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#9 out of 500+)... it's time for 

World of Goo is a physics-based puzzle game where we get to mess around with silly sentient spheres of ooze. The object of any level is pretty simple—move as many gooballs from point A to point B as quickly as you can. You can build towers and bridges, break down your towers or bridges, or hoist gooey-pink balloons on top of other, denser oozing inkblots to lift your structures into the air.

Though most of the levels are fairly simple, World of Goo offers some refreshingly quirky, downright silly art, with highly addictive gameplay. It's been a long time since I've been so engrossed in playing a game that I lose track of time, so when I looked up from my screen to see three hours passed since I first clicked on the icon, I realized I was playing a classic.

World of Goo is an utterly charming adventure that any gamer, or lover-of-fun would be severely remiss in avoiding. It's not quite perfect, but it manages to capture an element not-often seen in more modern games: it's a helluva lot of fun.

Note: also played on Nintendo Wii.

16635693.review:
Very interesting game...

Not only you've got to figure out how to build a less than steady structure to bring as many goo balls as possible to the exit, but also keep in mind that the free goo balls themselves won't stop moving and may bring down your structure with theirs incessant motion...
Do you think your structure could reach the Exit with what you think is the minimum amount of goo needed or should you add a few more goo to solidify your structure, meaning a less than perfect score?...

And how about a bonus level asking you to build the highest possible structure, with a limited number of goo balls, knowing all too well that all free goo balls will be attracted to the top of said construction and risking (and all too often succeed) in collapsing your carefully planned masterpiece...


A relaxed, but not easy puzzle game that have a undeniably charm...

16404653.review:
If you're looking for a puzzle game that packs both charm and challenge, then you've come to the right place. World of Goo is almost instantly addictive for players of all skill levels, with simple controls and play mechanics that are easily grasped.

Click and drag the adorable goo balls into position to construct towers, bridges, and other structures to reach your goal. You only have a limited number of goo balls, and since some of them need to exit the level safely, you'll have to avoid hasty decisions and start planning ahead. You must carefully consider where to place the next goo ball--and (when later goo balls with different abilities are introduced) WHICH goo ball to place. It may take a few tries (and retries...and maybe even MORE retries), but you'll feel a sense of accomplishment once you've nailed the goal. Even after you've beaten the level, you can replay it again later to see if you can figure out method of achieving the goal with less moves and faster times (the "OCD" goals in the menu beckon you to try this).

The art style is clean and colorful. All of the characters and interactive elements are distinctive on the screen, so you can easily focus on the task at hand. The sound effects are simple and cute, and the musical soundtrack is very well done. A large number of levels and a progressively increasing challenge means that you'll be coming back for more for a very long time.

This highly enjoyable game will put your logic skills to the test and bring a smile to your face. I highly recommend it!

16002729.review:
A charmingly cute little gem of a physics-based puzzler! The premise is elegantly simple: Link the adorable goo balls together to create structures and bridges to allow the rest of them to navigate the structure to reach the pipe at the end of the level - guided only by some mysterious sign-painter, who lavishes this with a quirky mix of humour and ennui

What's particularly brilliant is that the levels feel distinctly unique. For a straightforward idea, the puzzles are exceptionally diverse and really challenge you to think. Some are fast-paced, others are ponderous and require meticulous planning. Most are just plain fun. Solving it is also only half of the challenge... executing it is where it gets tricky; as you helplessly watch your lovingly crafted structure teeter and crumple into a pile of oblivious-looking blobs

New goo ball species are also introduced often, and really add their own distinct flavour to the game

My only gripe are the OCD flags. Level completion jumps between 'barely scraped by' to 'completed perfectly'. There's no half-way point to encourage players, so I didn't feel motivated to get them half of the time. You either have to do it perfectly or you might as well have not bothered (and the global highest tower isn't something I care for either). But that's a small gripe: The OCD flags are entirely optional (and hidden away) so doesn't detract from the casual element of the game if you want to just play it to enjoy

16000970.review:
[b][u]-Quick Review-[/u][/b]
World of Goo is an Indie-Physics-Puzzle Game developed in 2008 by 2D BOY. World of Goo is one of those quaint games that you would probably prefer to play on a mobile or smaller electronic device (with touch screen capabilities); in World of Goo you create bizarre contraptions with Goo to get to the end of the level.

[b][u]-Detailed breakdown review-[/u][/b]
[b]Story:[/b] You progress through the game being guided by "Signs" [i](or the "sign painter". But I always thought the signs were the side painter)[/i], you'll want to read every single sign in the game because they are quite humorous. The game is broken down into Five chapters, and each chapter would usually have 10-12 levels within the chapter.

[b]Game Play:[/b] Being a puzzle game, you need to spend a fair amount of time thinking, and once you get into the farther difficult levels, at times you'll need to restart the whole level because of one mistake. There is a requirement of how many "Goo Balls" you need to save at the end of each level to pass. So that means you can't use all your Goo on construction, you need to be as minimalistic as possible in your building.
The game starts out very easily and simple, but quickly gets complex and difficult. To construct, you click and drag a Goo Ball to a certain location near the starting structure to "add" to that structure. Generally after using that Goo you cannot reuse it... but some Goo has special properties that lets you reuse them, or have other special effects.

[b]Achievements:[/b] World of Goo has 8 Steam Achievements, all of which are pretty rough to obtain. [i](They went with Quality, not quantity)[/i] I only have 2 of those achievements at this time, most of them require perfect scores on each level... Getting all of the achievements will require a great deal of determination.

[b]Price:[/b] World of Goo is priced at $9.99, I spent 6 hours playing through the game once. So for me that's not a fair price.... However, I picked up the game on a 90% off sale, so I've actually gotten my monies worth, and then some.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] I recommend this game to people who enjoy puzzle and/or indie games, World of Goo was a very fun play through, and it only took one afternoon to get through it, so it's a nice quaint little play through. Depending on how good you are at puzzle games World of Goo does get pretty tough at times.

If you ever find yourself in an argument with someone over whether or not video games qualify as art, THIS game will win you the argument.  Hands down, World of Goo is one of the most fun and most fabulously creative games I have ever played.  I honestly love everything about it.  The level design is varied and the gameplay is challenging. Provided, of course, you dig the game's slightly surreal overtones. 

My only regret in buying World of Goo is that I did it seven years too late.  If I and others like me who took their sweet time had bought their own copies when WoG was new, we might have a sequel or something else equally amazing by now.

In conclusion, I urge everyone even SLIGHTLY interested in World of Goo to try the free demo and if you like that DON'T HESITATE to pick up the full version either on Steam or from the 2D Boy website (where you can get it on every platform, ever DRM-free for just 10 bucks more!) Please support these mad geniuses in their current projects by picking up a copy of the best indie game made in the last ten years.

You won't regret it.

14359320.review:
I wanted a fun little puzzle game that I could pick up and put down easily, but honestly this one is kind of annoying.  I would give it a 5/10 if there was a side-thumb button, but since there isn't I just can't see myself recommending this to anyone.   

The game is a very simple concept that, like any good game formula, has a lot of depth to it when properly explored (something I think the developers were on the right track with).  After a short time in the game, though, I found myself kind of disappointed with the PC options: resolution doesn't scale (as far as I can see from the UI, and frankly I'm not interested enough in the game to even look for the config files), config options are pretty much non-existant, no windowed mode option, and if you have multiple monitors your mouse can still go off-screen (despite the fact that this is a single-monitor full screen game) and if you accidentally click your game will be minimized (this causes issues when you're trying to edge-scroll from right to left, for example).  If these options exist they were not clearly visible in the main menu as far as I can tell, and with a pick-up-and-put-down game like this I shouldn't have to be spending much time configuring things anyway...Binding of Isaac is a good example of how to do a simplistic PC port.  

Put aside my gripes with the port (the reason I decided to not continue playing the game in the first place) the game just isn't that fun and there are some slightly clunky mechanics that get in the way.  The goo balls are constantly moving along your little wired network so you have to be rather precise with your mouse if you want to pick up a particular one in a crowded area, something that can be a major annoyance with the levels that require you to act quickly.  On top of this it was kind of annoying to discover that when you actually pick up a ball its hitbox is still present in the world, so if you accidentally drag your mouse over a harmful object you destroy the thing.  This turns the game in to one of those stupid games where you drag the mouse pointer through the maze and it detracts from the overall experience I was hoping to get.

TL;DR  it's not a bad game, but when a simple game can't deliver on simple and expected concepts I have no desire to play it.  Hell, if I could play the game in windowed mode I'd probably give it another try because shrinking it down would make it not look like shit.

Where to start with this...
I originally played this on a Powermac G5 when it first came out around the end of 2008, I remember that I originally got it sometime around the 2008 election. My attention was focused on this game the whole time.

It's one of those games where it seems extremely simple at first, but then the complexities and depth of it gradually shine through. The puzzles are neat, and I never had to use any skips until the last part (and I normally sucka t puzzles) but they don't feel easy, they feel satisfying regardless.

The visuals are nice, and they're crisp and good looking, and most importantly they do NOT resort to trying to look like pixel art. However, the game does run at a low resolution and there is no way to change it. 

The soundtrack... Well, let's just say it's one of the best soundtracks in an Indie game ever produced. It is well performed, it is entirely originally composed, and it doesn't resort to sounding like chiptune or 16-bit stuff to try and manipulate nostalgic nerves. One of the best parts of the game for certain, and even better is that all of the soundtrack (the full versions, not the shortened versions in the game) can be found right on Youtube. Very memorable soundtrack, I can say that about very very few games.

Buy it? YES! It's on sale frequently anyways.

12981266.review:
World of goo is a puzzle game about stacking "blobs?" all the way up into a tube. While this sounds like a terrible idea in theory, 2d boy pulled it off very well. 

World of goo starts off easy. VERY easy. The normal missions consist of stacking the gooballs in various shapes (such as bridges and towers) to reach your goal.

However, for completionists world of goo's novelty begins to rot very quickly. With every level, included is an OCD, which is the game's way of saying EXTRA GOAL. This usually consists of saving more gooballs or doing something extra. The OCD system is ridiculous. It is so difficult, it isn't even funny. This is one of the times where you're actually happy to skip past 100% and get on with the game because it is so unforgiving.

In short, world of goo is a fun casual game that is plagued by complex and ridiculous puzzles for the attentive and curious ones. However, I still recommend the game.

12951263.review:
An absolutely astounding game with the best audio I have ever heard. [b]"The Best Of Times"[/b] being one of the soundtracks for the game sounds just like pure classically composed music. The game is indie, and a puzzle game at heart, yet gives a real sense of story and gives you the sense of real progression throughout instead of just beating the levels in a somewhat drone fashion. Its audio, made by [b]Kyle Gabler[/b] has been and will be remembered for years to come. [b]Ron Carmel[/b] did an amazing job programming the game and the two did all of this work in coffee shops and in local parks. This game proves you don't need huge graphical abilities and 7.1 Digital Surround Sound to make people buy it. Nothing but pure creativity and real emotion put together into what I can say is my favorite game, [b]ever.[/b]
I wholeheartedly recommended this game.
